description: From Middle English shoten, from Old English scēotan, from Proto-West Germanic *skeutan, from Proto-Germanic *skeutaną, from Proto-Indo-European *(s)kéwd-e-ti, from *(s)kewd- (“to shoot, throw”).

entries.meaning: The emerging stem and embryonic leaves of a new plant.
examples: Prune off yet also superfluous branches, and shoots of this second spring.

entries.meaning: A photography session.
A hunt or shooting competition.
(professional wrestling, slang) An event that is unscripted or legitimate.
The act of shooting; the discharge of a missile; a shot.
examples: One underneath his horse to get a shoot doth stalk.

entries.meaning: A rush of water; a rapid.
(weaving) A weft thread shot through the shed by the shuttle; a pick.
A shoat; a young pig.
(mining) A vein of ore running in the same general direction as the lode.
examples: In the western dike is a shoot about 4 feet in diameter carrying a considerable sprinkling of cassiterite, ore which in quantity would undoubtedly be worth mining. The shoot contains a large amount of muscovite mica with quartz and very little or no feldspar...

entries.meaning: An inclined plane, either artificial or natural, down which timber, coal, ore, etc., are caused to slide; a chute.
examples: That there was no evidence before the jury that at the time of the accident the timber shoot was worked by the defendant company.

entries.meaning: (card games) The act of taking all point cards in one hand.
A seismic survey carried out with geophones in an attempt to detect oil.
examples: Once the last line of cable has been retrieved, there is little evidence that a shoot has been conducted.

verbs.description: shoot (third-person singular simple present shoots, present participle shooting, simple past shot, past participle shot or (rare) shotten)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To fire (a weapon that releases a projectile).
examples: to shoot a gun

entries.meaning: (transitive) To fire (a projectile).
examples: Synonym: (of an arrow) loose

entries.meaning: (transitive) To fire a projectile at (a person or target).
examples: The man, in a desperate bid for freedom, grabbed his gun and started shooting anyone he could.
The hunter shot the deer to harvest its meat.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To cause a weapon to discharge a projectile.
examples: They shot at a target.
He shoots better than he rides.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To hunt birds, etc. with a gun.
examples: They're coming to shoot with us on Sunday.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To hunt on (a piece of land); to kill game in or on.
examples: Although the estate had been shot previously, there had been no effective keepering and little success with the pheasants released.

entries.meaning: (gambling) To throw dice.
examples: Then, when it was his turn to shoot, he reached out with a completely empty hand and caught the dice the stickman threw to him.

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To ejaculate.
examples: After a very short time, he shot his load over the carpet.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, usually, as imperative) To begin to speak.
examples: "Can I ask you a question?"   "Shoot."

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To discharge a missile; said of a weapon.
examples: The gun shoots well.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figurative) To dismiss or do away with.
examples: His idea was shot on sight.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive, analogous) To photograph.
examples: He shot the couple in a variety of poses.
He shot seventeen stills.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive, analogous, film, television) To film.
examples: The film was mostly shot in France.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To push or thrust a bolt quickly; hence, to open a lock.

definitionGroups.group: To move or act quickly or suddenly.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move very quickly and suddenly.
examples: After an initial lag, the experimental group's scores shot past the control group's scores in the fourth week.

entries.meaning: To go over or pass quickly through.
examples: shoot the rapids

entries.meaning: (transitive) To tip (something, especially coal) down a chute.
(transitive) To penetrate, like a missile; to dart with a piercing sensation.
examples: a shooting pain in my leg

entries.meaning: (obsolete, intransitive) To feel a quick, darting pain; to throb in pain.
(obsolete) To change form suddenly; especially, to solidify.
examples: The north-east [wind] is loaded with vapor, insomuch, that the salt-makers have found that their crystals would not shoot while that blows.

entries.meaning: To send out or forth, especially with a rapid or sudden motion; to cast with the hand; to hurl; to discharge; to emit.
(informal, transitive) To send to someone.
examples: I'll shoot you an email with all the details

entries.meaning: (wrestling) To lunge.

(professional wrestling) To deviate from kayfabe, either intentionally or accidentally; to actually connect with unchoreographed fighting blows and maneuvers, or speak one's mind (instead of an agreed script).
To make the stated score.
examples: In my round of golf yesterday I shot a 76.

entries.meaning: (surveying) To measure the distance and direction to (a point).
(transitive, intransitive, colloquial) To inject a drug (such as heroin) intravenously.
examples: Synonym: fix

entries.meaning: To germinate; to bud; to sprout.
To grow; to advance.
examples: to shoot up rapidly

entries.meaning: (nautical) To move ahead by force of momentum, as a sailing vessel when the helm is put hard alee.
(transitive) To travel or ride on (breaking waves) rowards the shore.
To push or thrust forward; to project; to protrude; often with out.
examples: A plant shoots out a bud.

entries.meaning: To protrude; to jut; to project; to extend.
examples: The land shoots into a promontory.

entries.meaning: (carpentry) To plane straight; to fit by planing.
examples: two Pieces of Wood are Shot (that is Plained) or else they are Pared [...] with a Pairing-chissel

entries.meaning: To variegate as if by sprinkling or intermingling; to color in spots or patches.W
(card games) To shoot the moon.
(aviation) To carry out, or attempt to carry out (an approach to an airport runway).
examples: He tried to shoot the visual approach to runway 12, but the visibility was too low.

entries.meaning: To carry out a seismic survey with geophones in an attempt to detect oil.
examples: Once the area is ready to "shoot," the seismic crew places geophones and cables along the line of the profile to be recorded.
